DOM Cascade Examples

Understanding unify's unique composition system

ğŸ¯ Basic Layout Composition

See how pages merge with layouts using the DOM Cascade system.

Layout (_layout.html)

<!DOCTYPE html>
<html>
<head>
    <title>My Site</title>
    <link rel="stylesheet" href="styles.css">
</head>
<body>
    <header class="unify-header">
        <h1>Default Title</h1>
    </header>
    
    <main class="unify-content">
        <p>Default content</p>
    </main>
    
    <footer class="unify-footer">
        <p>© 2024</p>
    </footer>
</body>
</html>
+

Page (about.html)

<body data-unify="_layout.html">
    <header class="unify-header">
        <h1>About Us</h1>
        <nav>
            <a href="/">Home</a>
            <a href="/about">About</a>
        </nav>
    </header>
    
    <main class="unify-content">
        <h2>Our Story</h2>
        <p>We started this company...</p>
    </main>
</body>
â†“

Final Result

<!DOCTYPE html>
<html>
<head>
    <title>My Site</title>
    <link rel="stylesheet" href="styles.css">
</head>
<body>
    <header class="unify-header">
        <h1>About Us</h1>
        <nav>
            <a href="/">Home</a>
            <a href="/about">About</a>
        </nav>
    </header>
    
    <main class="unify-content">
        <h2>Our Story</h2>
        <p>We started this company...</p>
    </main>
    
    <footer class="unify-footer">
        <p>© 2024</p>
    </footer>
</body>
</html>
What Happened?

The DOM Cascade matched elements by class: .unify-header content was replaced, .unify-content was replaced, but .unify-footer kept its layout default since the page didn't provide it.

ğŸ”— Component Imports

Using data-unify on elements to import reusable components.

Component (_hero.html)

<section class="hero">
    <div class="unify-hero-content">
        <h2>Default Hero</h2>
        <p>Default description</p>
    </div>
    <div class="unify-hero-image">
        <img src="default.jpg" alt="Hero">
    </div>
</section>
+

Page Usage

<section data-unify="_hero.html">
    <div class="unify-hero-content">
        <h2>Welcome to Our Product</h2>
        <p>Revolutionary new features</p>
        <a href="/signup" class="btn">Get Started</a>
    </div>
</section>
Result

The hero component's .unify-hero-content gets replaced with the page content, but .unify-hero-image stays from the component since the page didn't provide it.

CI/CD Integration

Intermediate

Automated builds and deployments with GitHub Actions or other CI systems.

# GitHub Actions example (.github/workflows/build.yml)
name: Build and Deploy
on:
  push:
    branches: [ main ]

jobs:
  build:
    runs-on: ubuntu-latest
    steps:
      - uses: actions/checkout@v3
      
      - name: Setup Bun
        uses: oven-sh/setup-bun@v1
        
      - name: Install unify
        run: bun install -g @fwdslsh/unify
        
      - name: Build site
        run: unify build --clean --minify --pretty-urls
        
      - name: Deploy to GitHub Pages
        uses: peaceiris/actions-gh-pages@v3
        with:
          github_token: ${{ secrets.GITHUB_TOKEN }}
          publish_dir: ./dist

Common Patterns & Troubleshooting

Solutions for frequently encountered scenarios

ğŸ› Debugging Build Issues

# Get detailed build information
unify build --verbose

# Check which files are being processed
unify build --verbose | grep "Processing:"

# Validate your DOM Cascade setup
unify build --fail-on error

ğŸ” Development Workflow

# Start development server with hot reload
unify serve --port 3000

# In another terminal, watch for changes
unify watch --verbose

# Or combine both (watch + serve)
unify serve --watch

ğŸ“ Asset Management

# Assets are automatically copied from source to output
# Reference them relatively in your HTML:
<link rel="stylesheet" href="/assets/styles.css">
<img src="images/logo.png" alt="Logo">

# unify automatically handles:
# - CSS url() references  
# - Image src attributes
# - Script src attributes
# - Link href attributes (for assets)
